各位优秀的读者大家好！现在是选举季节，所以这些天的很多新闻——包括经济博客圈——都是关于特朗普与拜登的。这对于像我这样的作家来说有点困难——一切都非常有争议，有很多错误信息，而且谈论政策变得更加困难，因为一切都取决于谁获胜。尽管如此，我将尽我所能，在这个困难时期继续为您提供有趣且相关的内容。

本周的《经济 102》节目邀请了特邀嘉宾凯拉·斯坎伦 (Kyla Scanlon) ，她是一位创造了“vibecession”一词的经济作家，也是《在这种经济中？：货币与市场如何运作》一书的作者。我们的讨论非常热烈、热烈！

不管怎样，我们来看看本周有趣的事情清单。

1.欧洲开始意识到经济衰退是不好的

欧洲议会刚刚举行选举，大家都在谈论极右翼政党如何取得很大进展。但另一个重大事件是绿党的衰落，预计自 2019 年以来绿党将失去约四分之一的席位，其中法国和德国的席位损失尤其惨重。 普遍的共识似乎是，欧洲选民没有心情将应对气候变化的斗争置于生计问题之上：

在绿党的核心据点德国，自 2019 年上次选举以来，该党的得票率似乎几乎减半。出口民意调查显示，该党的得票率从 20.5% 下降到 12%，下降了 8.5 个百分点。在法国，极右翼势力处于领先地位，总统埃马纽埃尔·马克龙呼吁提前举行选举，绿党的支持率也下降了同样的幅度……

[绿党]传统上受到年轻选民的支持，其中一些人现在似乎已经转向极右翼的德国另类选择党 (AfD) 以及较新的政党……

政治学家怀疑欧洲气候政策是否存在广泛的抵制，但警告说，设计不当的措施 — — 特别是那些对贫困家庭打击最严重的措施 — — 可能会适得其反。

尽管似乎没有人使用这个词，但这里的关键问题似乎是去生长。尽管庆幸的是，为了应对气候变化而让人们变得更穷的想法似乎并没有在美国扎根（除了《纽约时报》偶尔发表的不加批判的文章），但欧洲知识精英似乎发现这个概念相当诱人。一些绿党支持者甚至断言，他们的政党失败是因为他们没有足够努力地推动去增长：

当然，这是完全狭隘和脱离实际的。事实上，欧洲选民之所以感到不安，正是因为他们的社会正在退化：

在民意调查平台 Focaldata 与路透社分享的一项调查中，在被问及影响他们投票的最重要因素是什么的公民中，“改善经济和降低通货膨胀”排名最高……“国际冲突和战争”是第二重要的问题，其次是“移民和寻求庇护者”[.]

尽管东欧出现了强劲的追赶式增长，但法国和德国等欧洲核心经济体的生活水平一直落后于美国：

1990年，法国人均GDP是美国的83%，现在已经下降到71%。自疫情大流行以来，这种差异只会加速，美国的复苏步伐突飞猛进地超过了欧洲：

这些是抽象的数字，但它们对应了欧洲人的日常生活逐渐变得更加破旧和困难的现实：

法国人正在少吃鹅肝，少喝红酒。西班牙人对橄榄油很吝啬。芬兰人被敦促在大风天使用桑拿浴室，因为那时能源价格较低。在整个德国，肉类和牛奶消费量已降至三十年来的最低水平，一度繁荣的有机食品市场也陷入低谷……根据通货膨胀和购买力进行调整后，德国工资自 2019 年以来下降了约 3%，下降了 3.5%意大利和西班牙增加了 6%，希腊增加了 6%。根据经合组织的数据，同期美国的实际工资增长了约 6%。

现实情况是，欧洲已经在拥抱经济衰退——也许不是故意的，但确实如此。这不仅使欧洲人变得更加贫穷，还使该地区更容易受到中国支持的俄罗斯入侵的迫在眉睫的威胁。

绿党向欧洲人传达的信息本质上是，这是一件好事——更快地减少碳排放的必要代价——而且该地区所需要的是更多的相同。欧洲选民并不认同这一点。

2. 不，美国人在就业市场上并没有被外国人“取代”

一群特朗普的支持者正在宣扬移民正在就业市场上“取代”本土出生的美国人的想法：

几个月来，推特上的右翼账户一直在宣扬移民正在将美国人赶出就业市场的观点。现在，英国《金融时报》制作的一张笨拙的图表无意中帮助他们传播了这种误解。

让我们应用我们的技术来分析病毒图表。请注意，此图表有两个不同的 y 轴 - 不仅级别不同，而且比例也不同。这使得本土劳动力的减少看起来就像是移民劳动力增加的镜像。这也使得本土劳动力看起来绝对在直线下降。但这些都不是真的。如果将两条线放在同一y 轴上，您可以更清楚地了解实际情况：

本土出生的劳动力数量与以前一样大，而外国出生的劳动力数量则小得多，并且略有增加。

如果我们看看本地出生的壮年工人有工作的比例，它实际上比特朗普统治时期还要高！

因此，自大流行以来本土出生的劳动力参与率小幅下降完全是由于54岁以上的人——换句话说，是人们提前退休造成的。本土出生的劳动力总数长期停滞是由于婴儿潮一代退休并且没有留下很多孩子。

换句话说，关于移民正在将本土出生的美国人赶出劳动力市场的“让美国再次伟大”论点完全是胡说八道。他们一定认为我们不知道如何阅读图表。

3. 对中国征收关税可以帮助其他发展中国家实现工业化

英国专家——甚至一些美国专家——继续猛烈抨击拜登对中国产品征收关税，而完全无视关税背后的核心理由。在他们的悲歌中搜索“军事”、“国防”和“国家安全”等词，结果却是一片空白。因为他们甚至没有解决关税最重要的原因，所以他们反对关税的论点不能被认真对待。

但除此之外，关税批评者还忽略了故事的另一个重要部分。关税为生产迁出中国提供了巨大的动力。但这并不意味着它会转移到美国——相反，它会转移到印度、墨西哥、越南、印度尼西亚、菲律宾等发展中国家。发展经济学家阿尔文德·萨勃拉曼尼安 (Arvind Subramanian) 写道：

关于中美竞争不断升级的争论往往忽略了其他国家，尤其是较大的发展中经济体的观点。毕竟，这些关税不仅是保护主义的，而且是歧视性的……今天的关税是对来自中国等被视为对手的进口产品征收的，将经济活动转向被视为盟友的第三国供应商……

印度就是一个很好的例子。自2014年推出“中国加一”战略以来，它成功吸引了多家西方企业退出中国。值得注意的是，苹果已大幅扩大其在印度的iPhone制造业务， 据报道特斯拉也可能效仿……如果印度能够建立一条供应链，在很大程度上独立于中国——电子行业正在缓慢发展的趋势——它可能会获得相对于中国及其相关国家的竞争优势……

美国的战略利益与第三国的能力和比较优势之间的重叠度越大，歧视性保护主义就越有可能长期存在，并为寻求多元化、远离残酷高效的中国的投资者提供确定性。

当然，萨勃拉曼尼亚是对的，但我认为即使是他也走得不够远！萨勃拉曼尼亚只关注将生产转移到中国境外的西方公司，因此他认为，越南和印度尼西亚等供应链与中国一体化程度更高的国家受益较少。但这忽略了这些国家将从中国企业将生产迁出中国中受益的可能性。

目前，拜登的新关税仅针对中国。这意味着，如果像比亚迪这样的中国公司在越南建厂，他们就可以规避目前规定的关税。最终美国可能会堵住这个看似的漏洞（尽管欧洲可能不会）。但与此同时，中国企业去其他国家建厂的动力很大。事实上，这正是他们正在做的事情：

事实上，中国企业也在印度投资，尽管担心从长远来看这将有助于印度成为中国的经济竞争对手。最终，个人激励通常胜过民族主义担忧。

即使你忽略这个问题的国家安全方面，你也应该同意公司将生产从中国转移到印度、越南、印度尼西亚等国家是一件非常好的事情。这些国家比中国贫穷得多，这意味着它们比中国更需要增长：

归根结底，西方和中国企业将工厂迁往新一轮发展中国家，只是旧的“雁行论”发展论的又一例证。但在这种情况下，鹅需要一点额外的推动才能离开中国。关税提供了这种推动力，全球穷人可能因此受益匪浅。

4. 租金管制有实际成本

根据我的观察，租房者，以及像 YIMBY 这样致力于让租房者生活更轻松的人，都对租金管制的想法非常感兴趣。毕竟，给租房者带来直接痛苦的是……租金上涨。因此，想要禁止痛苦的事情，让眼前的痛苦消失，这是可以理解的。

人们普遍认为，租金管制可能会对租房者产生一些负面的长期后果——这项政策可能只是暂时的拐杖，让未来的情况变得更糟。但现在就是现在，明天就是明天，总是很容易找到理由来说服自己短期利益是不需要付出代价的。

但现实是，长期成本通常是存在的。康斯坦丁·霍洛迪林 (Konstantin Kholodilin) 对租金管制研究进行了大量新文献综述—— 这是他引用的所有研究的电子表格——他得出的结论是，其缺点是非常真实的：

租金管制有用吗？还是它造成的损害比效用更大？……这项研究回顾了大量实证文献……租金管制在减缓受管制住宅的租金增长方面似乎相当有效。然而，这一政策也导致了影响全社会的多方面不良影响……

[A]根据这里审查的研究，通常，租金管制会导致不受管制的住宅租金更高。实行租金上限加剧了住房短缺问题。因此，等待的队列变得更长，潜在的租户必须花费更多的时间寻找住所......

同样，租金管制对新住宅建设和供应的影响似乎相似。大约三分之二的研究表明存在负面影响，而一些研究发现没有任何统计上显着的影响……[V]租金管制政策设计的变化可能很重要……[N]新建的住房可以不受管制，因此仍然存在不受租金管制法规的影响...

对于租金管制对住房质量的影响，已发表的研究几乎一致。除Gilderbloom (1986)以及Gilderbloom 和 Markham (1996)之外的所有研究都表明，租金管制会导致受监管的住宅质量下降。

因此，虽然租金管制为那些有幸居住在租金管制单位的人们提供了很多好处，但它导致整体住房存量变得更小、更破旧。这不仅提高了租金，而且让他们更难找到搬家的地方，从而伤害了那些不住在租金管制单位的人。

这并不意味着租金管制永远不值得付出代价。但这意味着有代价，主张租金管制的人需要考虑一下。

5. 如今服务成本增长缓慢

还记得那张图表显示医疗保健和教育等服务在美国变得越来越难以负担吗？

这通常是一个非常好的和重要的图表。这不是一个完美的图表——它夸大了大学费用，因为它忽略了经济援助，而且它的数据来源可能低估了 最近学费的下降。此外，它还使住房出现亏损，因为住房价格在绝对意义上上涨，尽管工资上涨更多。但这些都是小问题——总体而言，该图表准确地传达了这样一个事实：自世纪之交以来，尽管许多实物商品变得更加便宜，但大件服务的价格却变得越来越便宜。

但当你制作这样的“百分比增长”图表时，你选择的起始年份非常重要。如果改变起始年份，趋势通常看起来会非常不同。正如杰里米·霍佩达尔 (Jeremy Horpedahl)指出的那样，许多自 2000 年以来变得更加难以负担的高价服务实际上自 2013 年以来变得更加负担得起：

医院服务是这里的一个大异常，但总体而言，医疗保健已经变得更加便宜，大学、日托和住房也是如此。这真是个好消息。它带来了一些希望，即前几十年服务成本的大幅增长只是一次性现象，不会重演。

当然，这并不能改变这样一个事实：我们应该寻找方法让医疗、教育和住房变得更便宜。但这意味着阻止我们这样做的阻力现在可能已经减弱。这是一个重要的提醒：经济趋势并不是一成不变的。

; Three holes in the U.S.' economic strategy against ChinaLegacy chips, drones, and coordination with allies. https://www.noahpinion.blog/p/ Three-holes-in-the-us-economic-strategy https://www.noahpinion.blog/p/ Three-holes-in-the-us-economic-strategyNoah Smith Tue, 11 Jun 2024 00:21:41 GMT

现在写这篇文章几乎感觉有点毫无意义。在选举日之前，拜登政府在对华问题上无法采取更多行动，如果特朗普获胜，所有对华政策的赌注都将大打折扣。但我认为无论如何将这些想法纳入一般讨论是件好事。

美国经济政策的转变都是为了中国，都是为了国防竞争。正如叶格雷格（Greg Ip）所写，新范式由三部分组成——产业政策、出口管制和关税。关税保护美国的军事工业免受中国出口突然浪潮的破坏，产业政策增强了美国的军事工业，而出口管制则减缓了中国军事工业的发展。这些政策还有其他一些好处——脱碳、创造就业、技术进步等——但最终，中国与发达民主国家之间的防务平衡从根本上推动了这里的一切。

从总体框架来看，拜登政府的三大支柱还不错。产业政策尚未得到证实，关税如果滥用很容易适得其反，损害美国制造业，而且出口管制仍然存在很多漏洞。但总的来说这是一个合理的方法。

但这还不够。很容易找出新政策方法中至少存在的三个重大漏洞。正如叶所说，“第四条腿，即与盟友建立统一的经济战线，仍然没有实现。”与此同时，如果最终产品是在中国境外组装的，关税就不容易针对中国零部件。尽管芯片和电池行业的产业政策很重要，但美国仍然忽视无人机。

阻止中国“传统”芯片为一切提供动力

美国对中国的出口管制旨在阻止中国在先进尖端半导体制造领域占据主导地位。阻止中国在芯片制造方面取得进步的希望不大，但希望能够减缓其进步，使美国及其盟友能够保持领先。这就是为什么出口管制和其他一些限制在设计时考虑了“ 小院子、高围栏”的方法。

但许多计算机芯片并不领先。它们是“传统”、“后缘”或“基础”芯片（三个术语含义相同）。它们是较旧的技术，制造起来要简单得多——中国已经知道如何制造它们，并且拥有大量制造它们的工具。出口管制几乎不可能阻止中国在传统芯片制造方面取得进展。

但仅仅因为传统芯片在技术上不够复杂，并不能降低它们的重要性。正如 荣鼎集团指出的那样，这些芯片为我们经济中的大部分事物提供动力：

传统芯片无处不在，因此至关重要。几乎所有电子设备（包括汽车、飞机和战斗机、医疗设备、智能手机、计算机以及农业和工业设备）均由成熟的节点芯片与领先的处理器相结合提供支持。与流行病相关的限制让人们认识到，缺少一个芯片可能会阻碍整个制造装配线，让消费者难以置信，他们的新车可能会被剥夺通常被认为理所当然的功能，比如自动加热和调节的座椅。

目前，大部分芯片仍然在中国境外生产，但中国正在奋起直追，建造了大量新晶圆厂：

这些新产能大部分将用于中国，为中国消费者生产产品。但其中大部分将直接出口，或嵌入汽车和电子产品等其他中国制造的产品中。正如我们在汽车和电池领域所看到的那样，一旦中国加速其工业机器并开始向该行业提供大量补贴，其他发达国家的公司在面对冲击时可能很难生存。传统芯片是中国补贴最多的行业之一。

这可能会通过多种方式伤害美国及其盟友。

首先，来自中国传统芯片产业的竞争可能会淹没和摧毁美国及其盟国——日本、韩国、台湾和欧洲——以及印度新兴芯片产业的大部分芯片产业。一旦发生战争，这将使供应链面临危险。

它还将剥夺中国以外的芯片制造商用于资助尖端芯片开发的收入，使他们更加依赖政府补贴。摧毁台积电、英特尔和三星等公司的传统芯片业务可能是中国应对出口管制的办法。

最后，还有网络安全角度。一些人担心中国制造的传统芯片可能带有内置后门，使中国军方能够监视美国人、使美国基础设施瘫痪、将一堆美国设备和消费品变成砖块，甚至控制车辆并导致车祸他们。

因此，我们有很多理由试图阻止中国成为为其他国家制造传统芯片的国家。但如何做到这一点呢？铑集团 建议采取各种类型的贸易壁垒，包括关税，以将中国芯片排除在美国供应链之外。而中国芯片也被纳入了拜登最近一轮的关税之中。

但你不能对你根本看不到进入该国的东西征收关税。目前，美国政府对其进口芯片的来源知之甚少。如果一辆墨西哥汽车或泰国制造的笔记本电脑的某个地方装有中国芯片，美国政府根本不知道。这意味着，虽然阻止中国芯片本身的进口相当容易，但阻止含有中国芯片的产品的进口却非常困难。

因此，首要任务是获得有关美国进口的所有芯片来自何处的良好数据。目前，零部件进口数据仅来自经合组织，滞后了几年，而且甚至没有提供逐个产品和逐个公司的细分数据。美国需要实施报告和检查制度，为政府提供良好的、最新的信息，包括该国每个计算机芯片的实际制造地、哪家公司拥有制造该芯片的工厂以及哪家公司设计该芯片。

数据显然是这里最重要的事情。但我们还可以采取一些其他政策措施，正如 Steven Glinert 最近在Noahpinion 客座文章中概述的那样。其中包括 A) 对用于设计传统芯片的软件的出口限制，以及 B) 对传统芯片制造商提供更多《CHIPS 法案》资金或类似补贴。这两者可能只会产生边际效应，但它们可以成为贸易壁垒的补充。

但实际上，数据才是关键。看不到的东西是打不了的，而目前，美国政府根本看不到中国芯片。我不知道政府目前或计划采取任何措施来识别美国进口产品中的中国芯片。

打造民用无人机产业

美国的产业政策、出口管制和关税针对的是战略产业——芯片、汽车、电池等。但到目前为止，有一个非常重要的行业似乎被排除在这项努力之外：无人机。

到目前为止，很多很多作家都指出无人机已经成为现代战争的必需品。在乌克兰，大量无人机被用于侦察、炮击瞄准、摧毁敌方车辆，甚至直接杀死敌方人员。如果您能忍受，我建议您观看一架小型玩具无人机，配备简单的爆炸装置，在乌克兰战场上追击并杀死一名俄罗斯士兵。这架无人机是由人类远程驾驶的，但在不远的将来，无人机将成为由人工智能驱动的自主杀人机器。到那时，人类士兵是否能够在战争前线生存还是一个悬而未决的问题。

基本上，有两种为无人机提供动力的方式：内燃机和电动机。由内燃驱动的无人机往往更大、更重、更快、更强大。但电动无人机往往更便宜，并且可以大批量生产。 Shahed 无人机是最小、最便宜的内燃无人机之一，每架售价在 20,000 美元到 375,000 美元之间。相比之下，DJI Mavic 3 的价格约为 2,000 美元，而更大的 Matrice 300 的价格约为 13,000 美元。这两种类型的无人机在战场上都有其用途，这意味着任何无法制造或轻易采购大量廉价电动无人机的国家现在在战争中都处于劣势。

目前，中国企业在商用电动无人机制造领域拥有压倒性的高市场份额，其中大疆创新占据主导地位。第二大公司是美国的Skydio，但仍远远落后于大疆，而且美国没有其他大型无人机制造商。这意味着像乌克兰这样的现代战场正在被中国制造的产品所主宰。这意味着，如果中国与美国及其盟国开战，后者将发现自己没有大量小型电动无人机。

美国曾考虑禁止中国无人机，但据我所知，没有人谈论建立美国自己的无人机产业的产业政策。拜登政府似乎将无人机视为类似于导弹或炮弹——一种弹药而不是一种车辆，因此只有军方需要购买。但在与中国的持久战中，美国民用无人机产业将为美国军方提供重要的增援能力，就像二战期间汽车制造商制造坦克和飞机一样。

鼓励创建美国商用无人机产业的一项可能的产业政策是放松管制。美国联邦航空局已经大幅放松了对小型商用无人机的监管，但允许无人机在超视距 (BVLOS) 范围内操作将有很大帮助，因为这就是无人机在战争中的使用方式。 BVLOS 放松管制目前正在国会中进行，但目前尚不清楚这些变化将有多大意义。

但是，尽管你可以通过放松管制来鼓励无人机消费，但最终你会受到实际想要购买无人机的消费者数量的限制。对于电动汽车和计算机芯片来说，这不是什么问题，但无人机是一个利基市场，即使在中国也是如此。通常，制造商需要一个巨大的消费市场来扩大规模并降低成本。那么，中国企业是如何在无人机制造方面做到如此出色的呢？

Glenn Luk 在 2018 年曾就此发表过一篇精彩的文章，他指出大多数用于制造无人机的东西也用于制造手机。最大的例外是电动机本身，它更类似于搅拌机或其他家用电器中的电动机。

因此，美国的无人机产业政策只会激励在美国或选定的盟国制造无人机零部件——电动机、显示器、摄像头等。这类似于《通货膨胀削减法案》激励国内电池制造的方式，而不是类似于《爱尔兰共和军》激励电动汽车本身制造的方式。对这些组件所使用的消费产品（电话、电器等）的最终需求已经存在（事实上，其中一些需求已经得到了爱尔兰共和军的补贴）。

这项产业政策的成本几乎不会像 IRA 或 CHIPS 法案那么高，因为芯片和电池以外的电子元件相当便宜。但这可能有助于复兴国内消费电子行业，如果需要的话，该行业可以迅速转变为无人机行业。因此，尽管似乎没有人在谈论补贴电动机行业或显示器行业，但这似乎是一个有用的漏洞。

统一战线

重要的是要记住，中国比美国大得多，按附加值计算，中国的人口是美国的四倍，制造能力是美国的两倍。两国之间任何旷日持久的冲突都将导致美国严重落后，尽管美国在某些技术领域仍保持着微薄的优势。换句话说，美国的国家安全在很大程度上依赖于联盟——为了能够对抗更强大的对手，你需要一个团伙。

虽然美国在军事联盟方面相当擅长，但在经济联盟方面却不那么擅长。公平地说，没有人真正做到这一点——经济关系比国防合作更加多方面，因此没有标准模板来说明它们应该如何运作。但在一些领域，美国可以与盟友进行更密切的合作，以建立一个能够与中国相媲美的跨国经济。

最明显的领域是出口管制。如果美国想要有机会阻止尖端芯片制造技术落入中国手中，就需要荷兰、日本、德国、韩国和台湾等国家的合作。到目前为止，拜登政府在这方面做得相当不错。

其次，美国应立即寻求所有盟友之间的国防制造合作。美国衰弱的国防工业基础和缺乏商业造船业手段需要时间来修复；与此同时，美国应该严重依赖日本和韩国等伙伴来制造威慑中国所需的军事物资。幸运的是，已经朝着这个方向采取了一些举措：

美国及其印太盟友正在努力建立事实上的国防工业“共同市场”，制定相同的工业标准并加强彼此的国防工业基础……最近AUKUS合作伙伴之间放松了出口管制……经济学家兼国防分析师威廉·施奈德表示，建造核动力潜艇为盟国之间更多区域性国防工业合作创造了机会……

施奈德表示，日本在工业层面开展此类防务合作的时机尤其成熟，因为该国拥有强大的造船能力。

五角大楼负责采办和保障事务的高级官员、副部长威廉·拉普兰特将开始与日本同行会面……讨论合作。他将在东京召开美日国防工业合作、采办和保障论坛首次会议，邀请美国和日本国防承包商的代表讨论武器装备的联合开发、生产和维护……

“拉普兰特副部长正在推动的事情之一是联盟工业基地的概念，”施奈德说。

美国在这方面做得少得多的第二个领域是贸易。几个月前我写过这个：

中国的战略公司——华为、比亚迪等——可以进入一个巨大的市场。从某些方面来看，这个市场甚至比美国还要大，但美国、欧洲、日本、韩国等加在一起将是一个更大的市场。统一这些市场将使美国及其盟国公司——英特尔、波音、三星、丰田、空客、特斯拉、现代等——有能力扩大规模并降低成本。如果印度也加入进来，该集团将变得更大、更强大。

因此，只要美国能够将其联盟打造成一个统一的贸易集团，它就应该这么做。然而，挑战在于大多数其他国家并不愿意将中国从其供应链中剔除。如果该集团的其他成员只是充当中国商品的渠道，那么建立一个反华经济集团是毫无用处的。拜登政府已经做出了一些努力，让其他国家加入拜登的关税行列，但这些努力将不可避免地非常稀疏，而且效果也令人怀疑。

这里的一个想法是奖励具有战略重要性的盟国企业进入美国市场，以换取它们对华贸易政策与美国的贸易政策协调一致。这些公司实际上将面临一个选择——与美国做生意还是与中国做生意。与此同时，美国可以要求盟友向战略行业的本国公司提供类似的交易。

或者，如果美国能够设法获得整个供应链零部件采购的良好数据，它就可以与所有盟友签署自由贸易协定，然后对中国零部件征税。但这需要 A）更好地收集进口零部件的数据，以及 B）美国公众同意所谓的“贸易协议”。在两党共同努力推翻TPP之后，后者的前景显得黯淡。因此，真正的诀窍是在不引发贸易保护主义反弹的情况下获得贸易联盟的好处。

不过，总的来说，我认为更多地谈论经济联盟以及与盟友贸易和与敌人贸易之间的差异，将有助于美国公众为上述所有政策做好准备。美国面临着一个比我们曾经面对过的任何对手都更强大、更强大的对手，我们不可能单打独斗。我不认为特朗普或他的追随者会接受这一信息，这就是为什么民主党需要站出来并发挥领导作用。

电池一次解决两个基本问题

能源显然对每个工业社会都是至关重要的，它对于物理（“原子”）技术（例如运输，制造，电力和电器）尤其重要。我们经常从初级能源的角度来思考——也就是说，我们从哪里获得能源。太阳能和风能，核和水力发电等技术也提供了这种需求，当然，燃烧化石燃料也可以做到这一点。电池不这样做。

但是，能量不仅仅是产生。我们还必须储存能量，并且必须将其从一个地方运输到另一个地方。换句话说，我们必须在时间和空间中移动能量，以便我们可以随时随地使用它。电池解决这两个问题。

在存储方面，电池还不如化石燃料，因为它们会随着时间的流逝而泄漏能量。这就是为什么它们可以用于发电厂和网格的短期储能，但不能用于季节性存储。但是，对于运输能源，电池在质量上比化石燃料优越。首先，基本上可以通过任何电源来充电电池，而石油管道或天然气箱只能真正容纳一种特定类型的化石燃料。其次，从电池中提取能量通常要比使用燃烧引擎提取能量要嘈杂得多。还有其他优势。

随着电池的不断改善，与化石燃料相比，它们的缺点将减少。我们将开发具有更长寿命，更大功率密度等的电池。

唐纳德·特朗普（Donald Trump）在大多数民意调查中仍然领先，博彩市场使他比今年11月赢得选举的机会更好。因此，重要的是要考虑他的实际政策是什么，以及这些政策将如何影响美国人关心的结果。目前，美国人可能最关心的结果是通货膨胀。因此，我们应该在这里领先游戏，并考虑特朗普的政策将如何影响价格。

这是一个本质上困难的练习。特朗普不是与特定的意识形态结合在一起的，并且通常对说服力非常开放，尤其是如果您为他和他的业务带来大量支票。预测他是否会以有力和实质性的方式遵守自己的政策承诺，或者他是否会做出象征性的姿态并将其留下来一直很艰难。但是，如果我们要对谁应该担任总统做出明智的决定，那么我们需要做出最好的猜测。

这里的基本故事是，特朗普可以在美国增加通货膨胀的三种主要方式：关税，赤字和向美联储降低利率的压力。

关税和通货膨胀

许多人警告说，特朗普将通过提高高关税来提高通货膨胀。例如，这是Matt Yglesias ：

[T] Ariffs具有明显的通货膨胀影响……[考虑]进口橄榄油征收10％的税。这使进口的橄榄油更加昂贵……但这也将提高国内橄榄油的价格，因为外国人的价格竞争已经下降了……[n]想象一下，整个经济都这样做。一切的价格上涨。

特朗普已承诺，所有国家的所有进口税率征收10％的关税，对所有中国商品的60％关税，以及中国公司制造的所有汽车的关税。关税提高了消费者价格——从经济学角度来说，它们代表着负面的供应冲击。负供应冲击会减少增长，增加失业率和推动通货膨胀。因此，如果您关心通货膨胀，那么担心这是合理的。

关于高价提高价格的关税有很多不确定性。仅举一个例子：如果不采取行动减少美元作为全球储备货币的作用，关税可能会导致美元越来越强，这将使美国人能够更便宜地购买进口商品，从而消除了一些效果关税。对我来说，特朗普似乎不太可能采取贬低美元所需的戏剧性，挣扎的行动，因此货币欣赏是经济中的一支力量，它将“推动”抵抗关税的影响。 （当然，如果特朗普确实继续前进并贬值美元，那将产生更高的通货膨胀。）

实际上，根据一项研究，2018年的美元赞赏可能是特朗普在他的第一任期内的关税并没有太大推动美国人的费用的原因之一 - 总计0.2％ 。

由于这些不确定性，不同的模型得出了不同的结论，即特朗普提议的关税会增加通货膨胀。例如，彭博的经济团队预测，特朗普所有提议的关税的消费者价格总计2.5％ ，而鲁滨逊和蒂尔费尔德（Robinson and Thierfelder，2022年） 预测，仅仅全球关税就会增加6.7％ 。

这将是一次性价格上涨，而不是通货膨胀率的长期上涨。但是，正如我们在2021 - 22年间看到的那样，即使是暂时的通货膨胀率也可能使选民在一段时间内非常不满意，消费价格上涨6.7％。

因此，关税驱动的通货膨胀的危险是真实的，但是效果将是暂时的，并且实际上可能是适度的。但是，其他潜在的特朗普政策可能会产生更大，更持久的影响。

我们倾向于不将特朗普与通货膨胀联系起来，因为他的第一任期很低。但这并不意味着他的政策并没有导致2021 - 22年的通货膨胀。 2.2 万亿美元的《关怀法案》及其 2020 年 12 月的0.9 万亿美元后续法案向美国家庭发放了大量资金，甚至超过了乔·拜登在 2021 年发放的资金。美国人最初将大部分钱存起来而不是花掉，但在 2021 年他们开始花费这笔现金。大多数宏观经济学家认为，这种支出暴饮暴食在2021年和2022年初为通货膨胀做出了重大贡献。

随着美国的企业，投资者和家庭意识到美联储已被永久妥协和政治化，通货膨胀的期望很可能会上升，取消了沃尔克及其继任者说服美国人天生就是霍克什的辛勤工作。

关税，高和增加的赤字以及货币干扰的结合可能会将通货膨胀率恢复到1970年代的水平。正确预测2021年通货膨胀的拉里·萨默斯（Larry Summers）是正确的担心：

萨默斯看到同样的危险。他告诉我：“很难预测时机和精确的动态，但是很难想象一个政策套餐比直接提高价格（通过关税），破坏竞争的措施更有可能产生停滞的措施。 ，并过度扩大货币供应。他预测：“在特朗普总统任期内，随着通货膨胀预期上升，长期利率上升，我们将再次看到抵押贷款利率超过10％。”

在特朗普的第一个学期中，他很幸运。美国潜在的通货膨胀压力仍然相当薄弱，赤字逐渐升起，但仍处于控制之下，特朗普的早期关税只有很小的影响，美联储设法抵制了特朗普对其独立性的最初攻击。在第二学期，他可能会变得更幸运，但我不会敢打赌。

然后，第二个特朗普的术语不仅会引起痛苦和持久的通货膨胀，而且还带来了实际的经济灾难。

特朗普会引起过度通货膨胀吗？

没有人真正知道是什么原因导致某些国家爆炸成很高的通货膨胀。但是经济学家有一个猜测。基本上，这个想法是，当政府致力于经营大量永久性赤字时，中央银行致力于永久支持借钱创造借贷时，每个人基本上都放弃了该国的货币及其价值崩溃。

有些人认为这只有在各国失去战争或具有其他类型的地缘政治不稳定时才发生。但是，在发展中国家的许多超充电中，没有涉及战争或革命- 相反，无限赤字和无限赤字支持的货币创造的结合是由于一个国家自己的内部政治。在实践中，这通常意味着一个国家得到一个民粹主义领导人，他致力于通过向支持者和/或亲戚分发财政礼物来继续执政，并迫使货币当局支持这一策略。

特朗普会发生这种模式吗？不可能。美国是一个如此庞大的富裕经济体，美元是如此重要的货币，以至于需要大量的宏观经济干预才能将其变成阿根廷或委内瑞拉。但这也不是完全不可能的。而且过度通货膨胀的后果是如此可怕 - 委内瑞拉人实际上沦为2010年代的前现场生活条件- 即使机会很小，也值得担心。

现在，对于某些在特朗普的第一任期中生活的人来说，这听起来很愚蠢。特朗普第一次没有通货膨胀，为什么特朗普重新掌权，我们为什么要期望超高的通货膨胀？但是，值得注意的是，在大多数过度通货膨胀的发作中，在财政上不负责任的统治制度下需要多年才能爆炸。一段时间的情况看起来还不错，然后是BAM 。

例如，以雨果·查韦斯（Hugo Chavez）及其继任者尼古拉斯·马杜罗（Nicolas Maduro）为例。查韦斯（Chavez）于2002年成为委内瑞拉总统，并于2013年去世。事后看来，很明显，查韦斯（Maduro）继续是查韦斯（Chavez） 失败的经济政策- 最终导致了委内瑞拉的灾难性的过度充电。但是委内瑞拉通货膨胀看起来或多或少是控制的，直到查韦斯死前！

或以土耳其总统雷杰普·塔伊普·埃尔多安（Recep Tayyip Erdogan）为例，他是自2014年以来就职的民粹主义领导人，在此之前担任总理十一年。埃尔多安（Erdogan）不断迫使中央银行降低利率的政策导致货币的崩溃和通货膨胀率降至60％以上 - 不是技术过度通货膨胀，而是2021 - 22年美国通货膨胀高的六倍以上。经济增长停止了几年，只有及时逆转2023年的低利率政策才能稳定这种情况。

但是在2018年之前，自2004年以来，土耳其的通货膨胀率相对较低和稳定！埃尔多安（Erdogan）担任总统的任期已经四年了，自从他成为总理以来，他的政策爆炸了十多年。

这是我最担心的是特朗普和通货膨胀。 It's possible that the stable, tranquil macroeconomic situation during Trump's first term will convince people that Trump is a responsible steward of the macroeconomy, giving him political cover to engage in macroeconomic arson in a second term. Like Chavez and Erdogan — other populist leaders who feuded with their own country's institutions — Trump might exert a corrosive effect on American macroeconomics whose true damage isn't obvious until it's too late.

; How many of our "facts" about society, health, and the economy are fake?The rise in maternal mortality, the fall in geographic mobility, the rise in teen suicide, and many other "facts" are being called into question. https://www.noahpinion.blog/p/how-many-of-our-facts-about-society https://www.noahpinion.blog/p/how-many-of-our-facts-about-societyNoah Smith Thu, 06 Jun 2024 01:43:37 GMT

Remember the maternal mortality crisis? In 2022 and 2023, a lot of people were wringing their hands about how American mothers were dying at skyrocketing rates. Here's what the Commonwealth Fund, a health-care-focused think tank that's generally regarded as one of the top sources of public information on the US health system, told us in 2022 :

The maternal mortality rate in the United States has for many years exceeded that of other high-income countries…The US maternal mortality rate has been on the rise since 2000 and has spiked in recent years.

And in 2023, the Wall Street Journal declared that US maternal mortality was the highest it had been since 1965. These were only two of many outlets that reported on the trend.政客们注意到了。 Social media shouters declared one more piece of evidence of America's rapid decline as a nation.

There's just one problem: The US maternal mortality increase was fake. It was a thing that never happened .

In 2021, Joseph et al. published a paper in Obstetrics & Gynecology demonstrating that the entire recorded increase in maternal mortality since 2003 was due to a change in the way data was gathered. In 2003, US states began to include pregnancy checkboxes on death certificates.这导致更多在怀孕期间死亡的女性被认定为此类。孕产妇死亡率明显稳定上升是由于各州在不同时间采用了这一新复选框：

In fact, when the authors looked at the common causes of death from pregnancy, they found that these had all declined since 2000, implying that US maternal mortality has actually been falling . Meanwhile, a CDC report in 2020 had found the same thing as Joseph et al. (2021) — maternal mortality rose only in states that added the checkbox to death certificates.

So if the rise in maternal mortality was known to be fake as early as 2020 or 2021, why were prominent think tanks and news outlets still reporting it as fact in 2022 and 2023? Yes, it takes a while for research findings to enter the public consciousness. But how fast they do so is partly a function of how loudly experts broadcast new findings. And in a recent writeup of the maternal mortality debacle , Jerusalem Demsas uncovers one possible reason why the discovery that American mothers actually weren't dying at higher rates wasn't immediately shouted from the rooftops:

Christopher M. Zahn, the interim CEO of the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists, wrote a lengthy statement in response, arguing that “reducing the US maternal mortality crisis to 'overestimation'” is “irresponsible and minimizes the many lives lost and the families that have been deeply affected.”为什么？ Because it “would be an unfortunate setback to see all the hard work of health care professionals, policy makers, patient advocates, and other stakeholders be undermined.” Rather than pointing out any major methodological flaw in the paper, Zahn's statement expresses the concern that it could undermine the…goal of improving maternal health.

This is absolutely breathtaking, and not in a good way. One of the most prominent doctors in the field of obstetrics is openly arguing that positive data about US health should be suppressed , and that popular misconceptions based entirely on data artifacts should be encouraged to persist, in order to motivate the public to devote more resources to the goals he thinks are important.

To me, this clearly qualifies as disinformation. Zahn is demanding that researchers bury their findings so that the doctors, activists, and politicians he likes can get more money. That deserves to be a bigger scandal than it is.但正如德姆萨斯报道的那样，这种事情比许多人意识到的要普遍得多：

Similar arguments are rarely stated aloud but are highly influential behind the scenes: If you want to help people, you should show how they are in crisis. Anything that makes others more complacent about their problem is working against the victims.

This dynamic is evident well beyond the maternal mortality debate. A couple of years ago I reported on dire COVID-related economic predictions that didn't pan out : Among them were the eviction tsunami, in which 30 million or more renters would be kicked out of their homes, and the “she-cession,” wherein women would drop out of the labor market en masse.

One problem, my article noted, is that experts and activists alike have policy preferences—such as a preference for greater housing assistance for people at risk of eviction—that influence what they observe…One sociologist told me that high estimates of potential evictions may have been useful “from a lobbying standpoint.” “It was helpful to the movement of activists who were pushing for relief measures to be put into place to cite some of these larger figures,” a housing analyst told me. At the time, my assertion that these predicted catastrophes had not come to pass prompted a significant backlash.

This is exactly what I meant back in 2021 when I wrote that experts will sometimes lie to the public in order to further what they see as the greater good. It's also one reason why I believe that politicized science is bad and that science and activism don't mix .

But disinformation by experts is far from the only reason why the public gets misinformed about social, economic, and health trends. The unfortunate fact is that social science, public health, and any other fields that rely on observational data are simply not very precise . Data is hard to gather, and hard to interpret even after you have it. Causality is hard to isolate, and theories are hard to validate. Trends and other unobserved factors can change, so that what looked like a bedrock “fact” suddenly vanishes into thin air.

This is a big challenge for writers like me, part of whose job is to communicate research findings to the public. And it's become an even more difficult problem since 2010 or so, when the rise of mass social media vastly increased the amount of observational findings making their way into the public discourse. In fact, I'm noticing a steady drumbeat of stories about how “facts” that many of us regarded as ground truth in the last decade are now being suddenly called into question.

Is falling geographic mobility fake? Is the teen mental health crisis fake?

; At least five interesting things for the middle of your week (#39)Modi's third term; Biden and the border; good news on climate; nonprofits being bad; interest rates and austerity https://www.noahpinion.blog/p/at-least-five-interesting-things-e2f https://www.noahpinion.blog/p/at-least-five-interesting-things-e2fNoah Smith Tue, 04 Jun 2024 07:52:38 GMT

It's been a slow news week for those of us who don't write much about presidential politics — Trump's criminal conviction is sucking the air out of the discourse. But Noahpinion is always — well, OK, almost always — a calm oasis in the swirling storm of chaos and vitriol.

I've got just one podcast for you this week. On Econ 102, Erik and I discuss elite overproduction, and the future of the political Right in America:

OK, on to the list of interesting things!

1. Modi wins again. What's next for India?

Narendra Modi is an electoral juggernaut. Polls project his Bharatiya Janata party (BJP) to win an even more commanding majority in the current election ( Update : The election results turned out a bit differently than the exit polls, with Modi's party winning a plurality but being forced to accept a coalition with smaller parties). This will make Modi the first Indian prime minister to serve three terms since Nehru. That means Modi will probably be at the helm for almost all of the rest of the 2020s.

A few people on Twitter accuse me of being a Modi fan, because I cheer for India to have robust economic growth under Modi, and because I support the quasi-alliance between the US and India (which Modi has worked to further). In truth, I'm pretty agnostic about Modi. I take organizations like Freedom House seriously when they warn that India has become a less free country under Modi. That's worth worrying about.

On the other hand, it would be morally unconscionable for me to root for India to remain mired in poverty simply in order to decrease support for the prime minister. India deserves to grow, and Indians deserve to get rich, no matter who is in charge (and yes, I would have said the same about the Chinese Communist Party in the 1990s).

And as for US-India relations, it seems to me that whatever Modi has done wrong, his regime is still far more liberal and far less internationally aggressive than Xi Jinping's, and acts as a balancing force in a region badly in need of balance. America has a long and fruitful history of being pragmatic in choosing our alliances , and we should not change that now.

So yes, I am absolutely rooting for India to be a fast-growing strong country under Modi, and to partner with the US, even as I also urge Modi to maintain and extend India's liberal democratic traditions.

The next question is: What can Modi do to make India richer and stronger? Growth is already proceeding at a fairly rapid clip — poverty is falling rapidly , and the population is becoming healthier . Modi has done an excellent job on infrastructure, building large amounts of new railways and highways, electrifying the railways, expanding capacity and efficiency at India's ports , and so on. India is building vast amounts of solar power (which is why I'm not very worried about its carbon emissions). And the country's strong service sector is booming even more than usual.

接下来的工作是建立世界一流的制造业——印度需要实现工业化。 Fortunately, this is exactly what Modi has in mind :

Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi plans a raft of business-friendly measures if he wins a third term this week, including pushing through regulations making it easier to hire and fire workers…The premier also plans to reduce import taxes on key inputs for locally-made goods, which have pushed up India's manufacturing costs…The government plans to increase India's share of global manufacturing to 5% by 2030 and 10% by 2047[.]

That all sounds great, especially the reduced tariffs on intermediate inputs. Import taxes on intermediate inputs generally hurt domestic manufacturing more than they help — if you can't buy cheap steel, you can't make cars, and it's better to be the country that makes cars than the country that makes steel.

Lowering import tariffs is consistent with a strategy of integrating into global supply chains instead of trying to do every part of the production process in-house from day 1. Countries like China, Poland, and Malaysia have succeeded in recent decades by first courting foreign direct investment and doing assembly work, then moving up the value chain, and India should do the same.

Modi's push to “ Make in India, make for the world ” seems like the right approach. Apple is rapidly shifting iPhone production to India — in 2021, only 1% of iPhones were made in India, but this is projected to rise to 25% next year. Tata, India's top conglomerate, is getting involved and may emerge as a competitor to Foxconn. This is just the tip of the iceberg, of course — India is courting a vast array of other foreign companies, from Japanese farm equipment makers to Dutch semiconductor companies . Even Chinese companies are investing in India , despite fears that they might be training their replacements.

And Modi may also be doing something else I've long hoped to see — building larger special enterprise zones where India's famously harsh regulation is relaxed. More of that would be great, though a national push for deregulation of industrial land use would be good as well.

But there's one big thing Modi needs to be doing in order to promote Indian manufacturing: putting the country's women to work . Despite improvements in education, health, and transportation, India's female labor force participation is at an incredibly dismal 37% and falling . To my knowledge, no country has ever built a world-class manufacturing sector without taking advantage of large numbers of women who move from the country to the city to work in factories — it is a universal feature of industrialization. And women flowing into the cities would also help improve India's lagging urbanization rate.

So moving India's women from the farm to the factory should be a very high priority for Modi in his next term.

( Update : The fact that Modi's party lost a bunch of seats and ended up leading a coalition government instead of having an outright majority should make you more confident about India's democracy . India goes through periodic surges of illiberalism — the Emergency in the 1970s was another. But its democracy has never really been in doubt. When analyzing India's rise, I urge you not to think of it as being congruent with Narendra Modi. India and its system are much bigger than any one person.)

2. Biden gets tough on the border, but will the courts let him?

In many ways, Joe Biden has been the most progressive President in living memory — he has poured vast amounts of money into fighting climate change, forgiven lots of student debt, reinvigorated antitrust enforcement, pushed for trans rights, and so on.但他也做了很多重要的保守派事情——开发水力压裂技术，将石油产量推至历史新高，试图增加街头警察的数量，等等。

现在，在多年来基本上忽视边境危机之后，拜登变得更强硬——可以说比特朗普更强硬。他试图通过一项严厉的边境法案，但共和党为了阻止拜登在选举年获胜而否决了该法案。现在拜登正在准备一项行政命令， 禁止人们在美墨边境申请庇护，除非流入量降至较低水平：

白宫告诉立法者，乔·拜登总统正准备签署一项行政命令，一旦入境口岸之间每日平均接触人数达到 2,500 人，该命令将关闭美墨边境的庇护申请，仅重新开放边境据几位知情人士透露，一旦这个数字下降到 1,500 人……行政命令可能会立即生效，因为每日数字比现在更高……

政府律师一直在计划利用《移民和国籍法》第 212(f) 条规定的行政权力，该法赋予总统广泛的权力，可以在被认为“损害”国家利益的情况下阻止某些移民进入美国。特朗普在担任总统期间对移民采取一些最严厉的行动时也采用了同样的法律依据。

Progressive groups are already preparing to challenge the executive order in court.我不是法律专家，但我的猜测是，行政命令将被推翻，就像特朗普的那样。

这里的核心问题是，美国庇护法规定，如果你非法越境并向边境巡逻队自首，你就合法地有权请求庇护，就像你在入境口岸自我介绍一样。这并不意味着你会获得庇护——事实上，大多数涌入边境的人都不会获得庇护，因为他们实际上只是在寻找工作，而不是逃离战争或暴政。

但仅仅能够申请庇护就能带来很多好处。一方面，你的申请速度比在入境口岸等待要快得多——基本上，非法入境意味着你要插队。此外，您通常可以在美国等待庇护听证会。

换句话说，美国庇护法激励移民非法越境。这实际上与开放边界不是一回事，但向普通美国人解释其中的差异可能出人意料地困难。事实上，普通人在了解美国庇护法的这一关键方面时常常感到惊讶和愤怒：

这里显而易见的解决方案是修改美国法律，禁止非法居留者申请庇护（并修改允许非法居留者申请“暂缓递解出境”的法律，这与庇护类似）换句话说，解决方案是让国会修改美国法律，使其几乎完全符合拜登的行政命令所试图做的事情。

如果我们这样做，很多法律界的人会很不高兴，因为律师界有一个共同的观点，即申请庇护的权利是一项普遍人权。当然，即使我们按照我描述的方式改变法律，人们仍然可以在入境口岸申请庇护，尽管这会更困难、更危险。对一些人来说，人权要求我们允许人们非法越境申请庇护，从而使申请变得更加容易和安全。

但这种观点对于普通美国人来说可能没有什么意义。我们政府的一部分（我们的庇护法）应该鼓励外国人蔑视我们政府的另一部分（边境），这种想法似乎有点荒谬。美国人普遍对边境危机感到愤怒，他们对那些违法者并不抱有热情。移民对美国的未来极其重要，要保持对强劲移民的广泛、持久的民众支持，就需要制止非法越境的大规模混乱洪流。

不管怎样，真正的问题是为什么国会还没有尝试这样做。想必民主党人在某种程度上对那些希望让申请庇护变得尽可能容易的进步活动团体心存感激。共和党人可能只是想保留边界问题，这样他们就有理由抨击民主党人。无论如何，只要国会不改变庇护法，拜登的强硬行动能否持久解决问题就值得怀疑。

3.有关气候的好消息

那里有很多气候厄运论，而且这是非常无用和愚蠢的。但我可以原谅即使是理性的人感到有点悲观，因为地球气候的命运很大程度上不在他们所居住的西方国家的手中：

4. 非营利组织正在让美国窒息；美国终于醒悟了吗？

一年前，我写了一篇文章，谴责美国城市和州政府，尤其是进步地区的政府，将基本职能外包给非营利组织：

将政府职能外包给非营利组织是私有化的一种形式。重要的是，这是进步人士可以接受的一种私有化形式。但非营利组织几乎没有责任，导致成本膨胀和服务质量下降，并让不择手段的非营利组织高管将纳税人的钱装进自己的口袋。他们很容易与政治赞助人陷入腐败关系。人们只需看看旧金山就可以看到非营利组织政府的负面后果，旧金山制定了法律，以赋予非营利组织最大的影响力。

幸运的是，越来越多的美国人开始意识到这场治理灾难。我开始看到更多的专家赞同我对非营利工业综合体的警告。例如， 以下是《美国事务》中的乔纳森·爱尔兰：

当有人听到非营利这个词时，他们会认为这样的组织是为了公共利益而工作……听到某个东西是“非营利”时，立即给人一种该组织值得信赖的感觉，并且运营该组织的人是受慈善议程驱动的……因此，非营利组织获得任何其他形式的私人公司都不会享有的疑点利益……

结果……很少有足够的监督来保证他们正在做我们付钱给他们做的事……金钱的花费方式会让纳税人感到震惊，他们辛苦赚来的钱实际上被从他们身上偷走了。自以为是地宣称自己是无家可归者服务提供者的非营利组织，为了增加自己的资金，积极游说，使无家可归现象变得更糟……而非营利组织的高管，即那些声称目的不是赚钱的机构的负责人，却赚了数百万美元。美元，而灾难性地未能提供我们付钱给他们提供的公共服务……随着这一切的发生，相关非营利组织从国税局获得税收减免……

美国[进步的]城市地区正在不断提高税收，以资助公共服务……但这些税收收入随后被浪费在……不负责任的非营利组织上，这些组织的活动对解决问题几乎没有作用……税收随之飙升当地生活水平的崩溃和公共服务的衰退……非营利组织无法妥善管理服务导致欧洲对第三世界国家的能力征税。居民们不知道问题出在哪里：他们不知道他们的税款流向了被定罪的重罪犯的“暴力干扰者”；他们不知道经济适用房非营利组织使用纳税人的钱来游说反对经济适用房；他们不知道由于对非营利组织的监管不足，资金被错误分配。

爱尔兰接着描述了 TODCO 的臭名昭著的案例，这是一家旧金山非营利组织，本应为穷人提供住房服务，但提供的服务却很少，同时将纳税人的大部分资金花在 A）高管工资上，以及 B）游说反对建造新住房。相当吵闹。

但至少人们开始觉醒。一些进步人士，例如威尔·斯坦西尔，已经意识到非营利性私有化对整个进步项目构成的致命威胁。当然，另一种选择是通过加强公务员队伍来恢复国家能力，并让官僚接管许多现在被外包的职能。

5. 为什么紧缩时代即将到来

一段时间以来，我一直认为美国将不得不很快从赤字支出转向紧缩政策。原因很简单，就是利率。利率在很长一段时间里都处于很低的水平，但现在为了对抗通货膨胀，利率又有点高了。这提高了美国债务的偿还成本：

目前，政府显然希望加息是暂时的。短期政府借款的激增显然是利率很快会回落的赌注。

但利率可能不会回落到美国和世界大部分地区在 2000 年代和 2010 年代享有的水平。 5% 可能不是新常态，但有理由相信 0% 也不可能出现。 CEA 前首席经济学家厄尼·特德斯基 (Ernie Tedeschi) 令人信服地指出，由于各种原因，“自然利率”（通胀与增长平衡的利率）注定会上升。

其中一些理由是好的。更快的经济增长会提高自然利率，因为它会增加潜在的经济投资回报。生产率的快速增长，加上移民的增加，让我们有理由对美国的经济增长持乐观态度：

投资者可能会抬高国债市场收益率，从而推高[自然利率]，原因之一是预期生产率增长是否上升，这反过来意味着消费增长更强劲……[并且]自 2022 年以来，有证据表明，劳动力供给可能比通常测得的还要多。这种扩张的主要驱动力是高于预期的移民。

但也可能存在负面原因。美国国债通常被认为是金融体系中的“安全资产”，但如果美国政治不稳定，投资者可能会开始要求更高的风险溢价来借钱给山姆大叔：

[自然利率]的上升也可能部分反映了过去十年美国较高的政治风险，与财政风险无关。最近的一项估计发现，以股票风险溢价计算，美国的政治风险在过去八年里上升了 20-25 个基点。

泰德斯基还指出，高赤字会导致利率上升，从而使高赤字更难以维持。

无论如何，有很多理由认为利率可能不会回到原来的 0%。如果是这样的话，那么即使利率定在2%或3%而不是5-6%，国债的利息成本也将比以前高得多。这将迎来一个紧缩时代。

我最近写作的一个主题是与中国的战争威胁。我不认为冲突无论如何都是不可避免的，但这种可能性已经足够了，为此做好准备必须成为美国和其他地方政策制定者的主要关注点。但在过去的两个月里，很多人告诉我，我应该去中国，以便更好地了解其地缘政治意图。有人告诉我，如果我去那里，我就会意识到中国并不真正想要战争：

事实上，我实际上去过中国几次——最近一次是 2019 年的香港之旅，最终我逃离了警察的追捕。那么为什么人们认为再次去会改变我对地缘政治事件的看法呢？

告诉我这些事情的四个人都不是专业的中国骗子；他们都不是专业的中国骗子。他们都是我认识的人，都是我尊敬的人。他们只是真诚地相信，去中国旅行并与那里的人们见面是了解中国人想要什么的好方法。

现在，这里明显的对立之处是，一个国家人民的意志与治理国家的人民的意志并不相同。习近平并不代表普通中国人，事实上，除了极少数情况外，他甚至可能根本不听普通中国人的意见。正如赫尔曼·戈林在纽伦堡受审时所说，普通民众通常不会在战争后产生欲望；当他们的领导人决定将他们拖入战争时，他们只是支持战争。

在上海闲逛，你不会看到包围台湾的军舰舰队，也不会被允许参观以二战以来前所未有的速度生产军事装备的大型工厂。在餐馆里与商人交谈，在夜总会里与年轻人交谈。不会告诉你太多关于政治局和党国其他机关闭门谈论的内容。所有关于战争与和平的相关决定都将由你作为游客永远不会见到的人做出。

所以我的朋友们在这里显然是错误的。但他们相信旅游能够传达对一个国家及其人民的深刻了解，这让我思考：你能从海外旅行中真正学到多少东西？

为什么旅游业是了解其他国家的薄弱工具

事实上，我一直是海外生活的大力倡导者。早在 2021 年，我就写过一篇文章，认为其他国家的生活可以帮助你认识到自己国家的缺陷和优势：

但这与说你可以通过旅行来了解一个国家不同，原因有很多。

首先，看到其他国家并不等于了解他们，尽管这都是有价值的活动。如果你去日本看到他们拥有令人惊叹的火车系统，它会激发你思考“为什么我们在美国没有一个很棒的火车系统？”，甚至“美国如何才能获得更好的火车？” 。但它不会告诉你为什么日本有这么棒的火车。它不会告诉您日本的火车系统是如何建造的，或者为什么建造。它不会告诉您它的成本是多少或维护起来有多容易。它不会告诉您日本政府为了建造火车而必须克服的任何政治问题等等。

很高兴知道其他国家可以采取不同的做法，但这只是了解这些差异的第一步。

其次，一周甚至三周的旅行并不足以让你有足够的时间来了解一个地方。在海外生活，尤其是多年生活，可以让你与那里的人建立深厚的关系——同事、亲密的朋友、长期的浪漫伴侣等。它也可以让你了解人们的日常生活。生活——他们的工作日是什么样子，他们的房子是什么样子。你会体验到挫折和低效率以及便利。你会理解梦想、心碎和日常的快乐。

作为一名游客，您对这些事情了解甚少。您会四处走动并看到建筑物，但您不会知道谁在那里生活或工作。你会在餐馆和酒吧里与人们聊天，但你不会知道他们的秘密。你会体验到一个地方的表面，但不会感知到其深处。

根据我的经验，游客也容易通过观察公共建筑和基础设施来判断国家的经济状况。例如，东京就是一个视觉奇迹，拥有新建建筑的森林、完美的商店和餐馆以及美丽的公园。但只有在日本生活一段时间后，你才会发现很多日本人正在悄然陷入贫困。去上海或深圳可能会让你误以为中国是世界上最富有的国家，而不是中等收入国家——中国刚刚经历了世界历史上最伟大的建设热潮，而那些一线城市的一切都在资本折旧周期的开始。

当然，在一个地方呆上几年并不能保证你能深入了解它——有些人可能在一个国家生活了十年，但对它的了解却少得惊人。但这里有很多陷阱和理解障碍，如果您只短暂访问，情况会更糟。

例如，如果你在一个地方呆的时间不多，你遇到的人将很大程度上受到选择效应的影响——尤其是如果你不会说当地语言的话。如果你以美国游客的身份去中国或寻找投资公司，你的谈话对象往往是面向西方、会说一点英语的中国人。喜欢外国国家、说外语的人并不总是代表他们所生活的社会。如果有高度民族主义的中国人坐在一起谈论他们如何希望与美国开战，他们可能不会站在你的立场上。火锅派对。

最后，根据我的经验，人们倾向于通过先入为主的观念和已有的刻板印象来看待外国。在 2021 年的帖子中，我写道：

另一个陷阱是倾向于通过自己先入为主的刻板印象来看待其他文化。我见过一些西方人将日本街头时尚场景的无限创造力和自我表达解释为某种从众的表达，仅仅是因为他们一直被告知日本是一个“集体主义”国家（尽管调查发现从 20 世纪 80 年代中期开始，日本变得比美国更加个人主义）。我的一位澳大利亚朋友表示，她很厌恶在火车上看到日本人戴口罩（呵呵），认为这是源于挑剔的细菌恐惧症；我们必须向他们解释，这些人自己也患有感冒，并且正在认真地努力防止将细菌传播给其他人。

来自美国和其他英语圈国家的人们往往依赖刻板印象来了解日本，这一直让我感到惊讶。部分原因可能是露丝·本尼迪克特的《菊花与剑》和类似的书籍，但保守的日本思想家在理论化其文化的独特性时经常使用一厢情愿的想法，这也必须承担一些责任。

我应该指出，许多这些刻板印象完全是错误的。最令人震惊的例子是“内疚与羞耻文化”的概念——本尼迪克特写道，西方人服从他们内心的良心（“内疚”），而日本人则受到社会制裁的威胁（“羞耻”）的激励。相当多的美国人仍然相信这一点，但这完全是无稽之谈。

心理学研究和随后的人类学研究都与本尼迪克特的理论强烈矛盾，表明日本人强烈地受到内疚感和羞耻感的驱使。但你甚至不需要经过同行评审的文献就知道这是无稽之谈——即使没有人在场，日本人也始终坚持做正确的事情。一个典型的例子是，日本人如何将发现的丢失现金上缴，而不是自己保留，尽管周围的人不会知道他们是否保留了这些现金。 1日本人几乎不乱扔垃圾，即使他们可以不被抓到。日本人更加小心地将垃圾放入正确的垃圾桶，即使没有人会看到他们把它放在错误的地方。等等。

如果你问日本人为什么在没人注意的情况下做正确的事，他们会告诉你，他们担心给别人带来不便或伤害——这是良心有罪的典型表现。

然而，一些西方人仍然几乎绝望地坚持本笃的错误刻板印象。当我向其他外国人指出，上交现金如何表明日本社会是由内疚驱动的时，一些人承认了这一点，但其他人顽固地坚持认为这不是“内疚”，而是“内在的耻辱”——他们基本上发明了一个新术语，与本尼迪克特最初的描述完全不符，为了让自己相信自己的刻板印象从来没有错。

对许多人来说，这些文化刻板印象是认知不确定性风暴中令人欣慰的港湾。当面对一些可怕的新奇事物时，比如外国文化，我们会摸索任何能让我们放心的东西，让我们确信我们已经理解它了。

因为这些人在旅行时会带着他们的刻板印象，所以他们学到的任何经验教训都会通过这个镜头过滤掉。那些带着“中国人是一个和平、重商而不是好战的种族”这一信念去中国的人，在离开中国时往往会强化这种观念。 2那些认为中国是一个军事化、偏执社会、渴望为“百年屈辱”复仇的人，可能会强化这种想法。

即使是聪明的游客也很容易成为这些东西的牺牲品。例如，Wait But Why 博客的作者 Tim Urban 于 2014 年去日本旅行，回来后重申了一堆陈旧的文化刻板印象，他用这张相当搞笑的图表总结了这些刻板印象：

乌尔班自己承认，他不会说日语，只能非常粗鲁地与几个日本人交流。但仅仅两周后，厄本就以某种方式对日本人得出了非常深刻的结论，包括存在着西方人永远无法洞察的巨大的未被观察到的“内在心理”。

经过两周的点餐和问路，厄本是如何如此深入地了解日本人的灵魂呢？显而易见的答案是他没有。相反，他对所见所闻的理解来自于他读过的东西以及他与其他西方人的讨论。例如，他写道：

这种社会和谐在日本文化中根深蒂固，维护它至关重要——之所以重要，是因为在日本发生负面互动会给社会带来灾难性的后果，让你“丢面子”，这是一种令人难堪的经历。

这是直接出自《菊花剑》的。但厄本相信，他在乡下呆了两周就推断出了这一点！这就是先入为主的力量。

我不想对蒂姆·厄本（Tim Urban）或者我喜欢去中国旅行的朋友太严厉。去一个新地方并形成对它的印象绝对没有错。我做。好有趣！但你不应该欺骗自己，认为这可以让你预测一个国家的经济或地缘政治命运。

为什么你还是应该去旅行

但说完这些之后，我想强调的是，我认为国际旅行是一件非常好的事情，而且你实际上可以从中学到很多东西。那么你能学到什么？

首先，就像在海外生活一样，旅行可以帮助你了解自己的国家。如果你在一个地方长大并终生生活在那里，你可能无法想象还有其他生活方式是可能的；旅行会让你打消这个念头。许多美国人去日本回来后希望美国能有更好的火车系统，或者机场安检不让你脱鞋。或者他们去阿姆斯特丹，回来后希望美国对自行车更加友好。或者他们去新加坡，回来时希望美国能够拥有充足的住房和超低的犯罪率。观察其他国家的优势会告诉你，在国内也可能会发生更好的事情。

另一方面是旅行可以帮助你更加欣赏自己的国家。 If you think the average American lives a life of material poverty, a trip to Europe or Japan might make you realize that even most other rich countries' living standards are far behind the United States . If you never stopped to think about how amazing American grocery stores are, in terms of both quality and selection, a visit to a supermarket in another country may increase your appreciation of Safeway, Kroger, and (especially) HEB . If you think America is an unruly country full of disruptive riots and protests, you should spend some time in France.

Another reason to travel is that simply exposing yourself to different cultures can make you less afraid of difference in general, even if you never really understand what you see. Cao, Galinsky, and Maddux (2014) found a number of studies with a breadth of fairly credible research designs, all of which agree that travel increases social trust:

Five studies examined the effect of breadth and depth of foreign experiences on generalized trust. Study 1 found that the breadth (number of countries traveled) but not the depth (amount of time spent traveling) of foreign travel experiences predicted trust behavior in a decision-making game. Studies 2 and 3 established a causal effect on generalized trust by experimentally manipulating a focus on the breadth versus depth of foreign experiences. Study 4 used a longitudinal design to establish that broad foreign travel experiences increased generalized trust. Study 5 explored the underlying processes and found that a focus on the differences rather than the similarities among the countries visited was critical in producing greater generalized trust. Across five studies, using various methods (correlational, lab experiment, and longitudinal), samples (United States and Chinese) and operationalizations (trust game and generalized trust scale), we found a robust relationship between the breadth of foreign travel experiences and generalized trust 。

This is probably just a form of the contact hypothesis , which says that being around people who are different than you makes you feel more favorably toward them. It's also probably the same reason that big cities tend to be more liberal than small towns — cosmopolitanism breeds tolerance.

Going overseas can also help disabuse you of a few of your preconceptions. Turkey — or at least, Istanbul — felt much richer and more modern than I might have mentally expected. Parisians were a lot warmer and friendlier than I had expected. Germany was less urbanized than I was expecting. These updates weren't anything earth-shattering, but they did help me get a bit more of a complete and up-to-date picture of what the world looks like nowadays.

Finally, even if overseas trips don't give you answers about why other countries are the way they are, they can motivate you to start asking questions . Traveling to Taiwan made me wonder why the streets are laid out so differently than in Japan, why the buildings aren't as new-looking, and so on. Traveling to Ireland made me wonder how the country went from centuries of poverty to material comfort and wealth almost overnight. Traveling to Singapore made me wonder how they manage to build so much housing, how they became much richer than the US, and how they manage not to have any bugs despite having a bunch of plants on the sides of buildings.等等。

You can learn the answers to these questions — it just requires time and research.

As for China, I definitely agree with my friends that people should travel there and see it for themselves. No, it won't tell you whether they're going to start a war. But you can ride great high-speed trains, pay for everything with one app, get stuff delivered to your door by robot, and see a lot of pretty LEDs on the sides of buildings. If you're an American, you can see the salutary example of a country that actually builds things , instead of allowing local NIMBYs to force the built environment into a crumbling ruin.

You can probably eat some pretty good food, too.

Interfering with markets in a rich country requires a justification. Markets, if they're properly regulated, are a very efficient way to maximize a nation's overall income. Problems of inequality and poverty can be solved through redistribution and measures to improve worker bargaining power; the occasional recession can be dealt with through monetary and fiscal stimulus. This basic formula — call it the neoliberal/social-democratic mixed economy — has produced the most highly developed and happiest societies on Earth. If you're going to mess with that formula by having the government come in and start mucking around with a country's industrial structure, you need a good reason.

The US and our democratic allies have a very good reason: national security . The China-Russia Axis requires democracies to rebuild and enhance their own manufacturing industries, and this requires interfering in the free market in some way. Industrial policy is a big part of that .

But those national security concerns only really became widespread in the past five years. The shift in US economic thinking was actually underway well before that. I remember in 2017, going to a Bloomberg conference where almost everyone — mostly a bunch of progressive intellectuals from tech, think tanks, and the media — was talking about the need to bring industrial policy back. But China was never mentioned — the big justification that everyone cited was climate change .

I remember hearing everyone talk about how the fight against climate change required an industrial mobilization on the order of World War 2 — to build green energy, switch to EVs, revamp our industrial processes, and refit or rebuild buildings. A shift in a nation's economic policy requires both parties to be on board — not generally through bipartisan cooperation, but by competing to put their own stamp on the basic paradigm. Eisenhower and Nixon both left their imprints on the New Deal, while Carter and Clinton implemented key parts of the “neoliberal” revolution. Most Democrats and a majority of Republicans are definitely on board with national security, and both understand the importance of industrial policy in that realm. But the GOP simply rejects climate policy as a guiding orientation for the US economy.

So climate change will remain divisive. That won't make climate policy impossible, but it will prevent it from becoming the central, overriding imperative of economic policymaking.

Fortunately, it doesn't need to be.

The green energy transition will happen even if climate isn't always Priority #1

The gains from reducing US emissions are modest but far from trivial. Some analyses find that Biden's economic policies would result in a decrease of approximately 1.7 billion tons of CO2 equivalent emissions by 2030 compared to Trump's policies. That's about 4.6% of global emissions in 2022 — not a huge amount, but not nothing either. China will still be more important than the US for the fight against climate change (and there are hopeful signs that it's doing better these days), but the US can certainly do a lot to help.

Here's where US greenhouse gas emissions come from:

In order to decarbonize, we need to do the following four things:

  1. Switch to green energy — mostly solar backed up by battery storage, but with some nuclear and wind as well

  2. Switch to electric cars, buses, and other vehicles

  3. Electrify home heating (and cooking)

  4. Electrify a bunch of industrial processes like steel and cement, or use other green equivalents

Basically, you can boil this down to 1) electrify everything, and 2) make sure that the electrical grid itself runs off of green energy.

Fortunately, two miraculous technologies have emerged to make both of these tasks much, much, much easier than they would have been back in 2010 or 1990. Solar and batteries are on steep learning curves — as we produce more and more of them, their prices have plummeted exponentially. As a result, solar is on a faster expansion path than any energy technology in history:

A recent report by Ember found that solar and wind now generate around 12% of global electricity — that's actual generation, not “capacity”. When you add that to existing hydropower, renewables now generate around 30% of the world's electricity, and rising fast:

The US is not lagging here. In March, according to the EIA , solar and wind generated 21.2% of US electricity, renewables generated 29.9%, and renewables and nuclear combined generated 49.4%.

Although Biden's climate policies are great, they haven't had much chance to take effect yet, and many countries don't have similar policies in place. The rapid shift toward renewables is being driven by technological improvements that make renewable energy — especially solar and batteries — really cheap.

We can see this just by observing the actions of countries and states that care much much more about economic growth than about climate change.

India, despite suffering intense heat waves, makes growth its overriding priority and reserves the right to continue using fossil fuels on the grounds that Western countries industrialized using fossil fuels in their day. And yet in the first quarter of this year, solar installation in India was up by more than a factor of six since last year.

And Texas, a deeply conservative state that's also the center of America's fossil fuel industry, is outpacing California and everybody else in terms of building solar:

In fact, solar and wind are proving to be Texas' most reliable sources of electricity .

Meanwhile, Texas and California are adding massive amounts of battery storage that is smoothing out the daily intermittency of solar power (ie, you can store energy for when it's nighttime or raining). That still leaves seasonal intermittency to deal with (the sun is weaker in winter), but that's a much easier problem to solve; at the very least, you can overbuild more solar.

In other words, solar with battery storage is proving that it's now simply the cheapest form of energy to build — provided you can get the land, get through the permitting process, and hook it up to the grid. And this is all happening with tariffs of 25% on Chinese solar panels, too.

Now, you could worry that Biden raising tariffs on Chinese solar panels from 25% to 50% will put an end to the solar boom. But it won't. First of all, solar panels have gotten so cheap that the cost of the panels themselves is only a small percent of the cost of a solar system — most of it is the land cost, installation labor, etc. So the new tariffs will raise the price of solar by a couple of percentage points at most — not nearly enough to affect the cost calculation of solar vs. coal or gas. And second, US solar manufacturing capacity by itself is enough to meet half the country's needs, without even taking into account imports from places like Mexico or Canada.

Tariffs on batteries going from 7.5% to 25% might be a more significant factor, given China's dominance of the battery market, and the fact that battery storage is pretty essential for solar power. But battery costs are forecast to drop 40% over the next two years, more than canceling out the tariff. Meanwhile, US battery capacity is ramping up pretty quickly, and is on track to meet all demand for electric vehicles, so adding capacity to meet the needs of electrical grid storage should be doable, even if we don't consider imports from countries like Mexico和加拿大。 EV batteries can act as grid storage too . And the US has plenty of lithium to make batteries.

In other words, the technological revolution now well underway in solar and batteries will usher in the age of green electricity regardless of tariffs. What's most needed now in order to accelerate the transition even further are regulatory changes — permitting reform , easing of land use restrictions, and reform of the outdated and inefficient interconnection queue system for hooking power up to the grid.

The other big shift the US is to switch to electric vehicles. Transportation represents the biggest single category of US emissions, so this is very important. And it's here that tariffs might have a bigger effect. Biden's 100% tariffs on Chinese-made EVs are high enough that they effectively constitute a total ban. And China is the country that makes the world's cheapest EVs — and probably the highest-quality EVs too, at this point. So it's reasonable for David Fickling and Dylan Matthews to be concerned.

But so far, even without any significant amount of EV imports from China, the transition to EVs in the US has been going fine :

For every sign of an EV slowdown, another suggests an adolescent industry on the verge of its next growth spurt. In fact, for most automakers, even the first quarter was a blockbuster. Six of the 10 biggest EV makers in the US saw sales grow at a scorching pace compared to a year ago — up anywhere from 56% at Hyundai-Kia to 86% at Ford. A sampling of April sales similarly came in hot .

The slowdown this year in US EV sales has nothing to do with China; it's all about Tesla suddenly failing to offer new products (including a promised cheaper EV). Tesla still makes most of the EVs that Americans buy, but the company has been faltering lately . That means there will be a lull in sales as other automakers — American companies, but also German and Korean companies — ramp up from a low base. But ramp up they will, and the EV boom will continues, especially as batter capacity expands and costs keep coming down.

And eventually, a tipping point will come where EVs just rapidly take over the entire auto fleet in the US Here's how I explained it in a post last year :

There's a network effect between gas stations and cars on the road — the more gas stations there are, the more convenient it is to drive, and the more people drive, the more profitable it is to run a gas station. This is why we have a lot of cars and a lot of gas stations; they reinforce each other.

By taking internal combustion traffic off the road, EVs are going to make gas stations less profitable to run. Gas stations have fixed costs that they need to make up for by catering to large volumes of customers; when they can cater to fewer customers, their fixed costs are harder to pay, and some go out of business (or switch entirely to EV charging stations). When the number of gasoline-powered cars on the road goes down by double-digit percentages, it's going to lead to a lot of closures or conversions.

When some gas stations vanish, it makes it harder to drive an internal combustion car as your primary mode of transport. This is because gas stations are fewer and farther between. This creates range anxiety if you're on a long trip, but it also just forces you to drive farther and every time you fill up. That gives people an incentive to switch to an electric.

Now, it's true that a flood of cheap Chinese imports would probably make this tipping point happen a bit sooner —Chinese EVs would be a bit cheaper than Teslas or Kias, and this would spur modestly faster adoption. But the emissions benefits of that modest acceleration would be more limited than people think. The reason is that the manufacturing processes for EVs are not yet decarbonized, and so EVs produced today have only modest life-cycle emissions benefits compared to ICE cars. That will change in a few years, of course, as the electrical grid decarbonizes and as EVs are used to make more EVs. But enticing a few Americans to switch to EVs a few years earlier than they otherwise would will have only limited benefits for the climate.

In other words, the green energy transition in the US is already happening, driven first and foremost by technological advancements, with Biden's industrial policy giving an extra push. The biggest bottlenecks in that push are regulatory barriers — NEPA and other permitting reform laws, the broken grid interconnection system, and so on — rather than a lack of sufficiently cheap Chinese imports.

Climate policy as part of a bigger industrial strategy

Meanwhile, some progressives are now making persuasive arguments that Biden's approach, tariffs and all, is the right long-term approach. Robinson Meyer writes that by keeping US manufacturers in the political coalition for climate action, protectionism will actually help sustain the political will for continued decarbonization, even in the face of Republican hostility:

This is the guiding logic of Biden's climate policy: that American politics must have a powerful, durable, and flexible pro-decarbonization coalition if the US is to succeed in reaching net zero. Achieving this coalition is the underlying aim of the IRA, the EPA rules, and — yes — the recent tariffs. This is what I wish critics understood about the president's climate strategy: Biden's strategy won't have succeeded if the US makes some headway on emissions but imports all of its decarbonization tech from China. The US actually has to develop its own supply chain and manufacturing base to build the kind of deep economic coalition that can sustain long-term decarbonization. This is why trade restrictions have become so central to the administration's world view.

The argument here is that if the US gets slightly cheaper Chinese imports for a couple years, but this puts Detroit out of business and destroys the nascent US battery manufacturing industry that Biden has worked so hard to build, it will cause a backlash against climate policy 。 But if climate policy remains wedded to American factory jobs, revitalization of declining American regions, and the profits of American companies, then even GOP culture wars won't be able to kill it.

I don't know whether Meyer is right, but this seems very plausible. As noted above, the political coalition for climate policy by itself is very weak, and apathy about the issue is widespread. But if climate policy is wedded to industrialism — which, yes, includes protectionism — the number and diversity of stakeholders in climate policy goes up dramatically.

Zachary Carter, meanwhile, argues that maintaining US domestic industrial capacity is superior to relying entirely on the Chinese:

Where the fight against climate change is concerned, more is more, and friends of both the planet and geopolitical stability should want the world's largest economy to be involved in the green technology of the future. To that end, Biden's tariffs are a necessary step…Tariffs can't do the work of economic development alone. They'll have to be harmonized with green tech subsidies from Biden's Inflation Reduction Act, coordinated with international allies, and adjusted in response to geopolitical change.

I think this is a good argument, but it's a little vague as written, so let me try to flesh it out. If China massively subsidizes batteries, EVs, and solar panels, and if the US opens its markets to these products completely, it will incur long-term risks. For example, a war with China, or other geopolitical tensions, could abruptly cut off America's source of green tech products. Imagine if 70% of Americans drive Chinese-made EVs, and suddenly China cuts off trade so that Americans can't buy new cars or get replacement parts — or even uses built-in backdoors to turn everyone's car into a brick. That would leave many Americans just as helpless and stranded as when the Saudis reduced oil supplies in 1973 or Iran cut off oil in 1979.

That risk, in turn, will make Americans wary about climate policy. If fighting climate change means making their livelihoods dependent on the whim of the Chinese government, they will be unlikely to embrace it. But if climate policy means building up US domestic industrial capacity, it will be more robust to shocks, and therefore less risky for Americans.

Carter's idea, in a nutshell, is that it's good for a country to have some degree of control over the technologies that are essential to its policy goals. That is a smart and reasonable argument.

In other words, the 2010s dream that climate change would be the moral equivalent of war — an overriding, unifying national challenge that would spur deep changes in America's economic system — is not going to come true. But something even better is probably going to come true. Climate policy is going to be one piece of an integrated suite of policies for reindustrializing America. National security will be the top priority, but thanks to progress in green energy technology, that imperative will also entail switching America to solar and batteries. And because climate policy will be wedded to a broad coalition of stakeholders, it'll be at least somewhat insured against cancellation by Republican antipathy and voter apathy.

Climate policy isn't going to drive the car, but it will be along for the ride.

Half a year ago, when I wrote that a lot of what we see in the news can be explained by the existence of a cold war between a China/Russia bloc and a democratic bloc, it was a controversial thesis. Now it's becoming conventional wisdom, and attention is shifting toward how to prevent Cold War 2 from becoming World War 3 .

Diplomat and international relations professor Philip Zelikow has a truly excellent essay about our present moment in geopolitics, which I encourage you to read. He argues that the Axis, the Soviet-China partnership at the beginning of Cold War 1, and the present quasi-alliance between China, Russia, Iran, and North Korea all have much in common. Their overriding goal is to topple the United States. This means that the US can't simply withdraw behind its oceans and adopt a posture of isolation or neutrality; the US itself, and its power and wealth, is the target.

Zelikow also argues that the mid-2020s are very similar not just to the 1930s (as everyone talks about), but also to the late 1940s and early 1950s. In those decades, a third world war almost broke out between the US and the USSR/China. The Korean War happened, China invaded Korea as part of that war, and the USSR almost invaded Yugoslavia. Only strong deterrence by the US, the caution of Stalin and Mao, and distrust between the USSR and China averted the danger. Now, Zelikow argues, we're in another critical period. It all depends on the choices of the leaders of the New Axis (my term, not his), and here he is not optimistic:

I believe the anti-American partnership has probably decided to double down. They are probably preparing in earnest for a period of major confrontation. My view on this rests on my analysis of the history presented above as well as some key assessments of Moscow, Tehran, Beijing, and — to a lesser extent — Pyongyang.

Xi and Putin regard themselves as world-historical men of destiny. They believe they are capable of decisive, strategic action. Xi ranks himself with Mao and Stalin. Putin evokes the memory of Peter the Great. In China, Russia, and Iran the information and decision environments are cloistered…In China, Russia, and Iran the propaganda ministries have already been preparing their populations for a time of war, great sacrifice, and existential struggle.

And he warns that the US no longer has the industrial strength to win a direct confrontation, as it did in former conflicts:

China is preparing for war. I am not saying it seeks a war. But, publicly and privately, the Chinese Communist Party is mobilizing its country for one…For the last 10 years, China has been working hard on preparing and refining its plans for national defense mobilization…One lesson to them from the Ukraine war is the shallow and fragile character of the US defense-industrial base. Yet despite an uptick in spending after Russia's invasion of Ukraine, Michael Brown notes that “America has a smaller military with older and less equipment than at any time in memory.”

He predicts that China will move on Taiwan with a blockade rather than an invasion, attempting to bring the island to its knees by simply asserting that it's a Chinese province and daring any outside powers to treat it otherwise. A blockade, in contrast, would dare Taiwan and its protectors to make escalatory moves, while at least offering the possibility of a cheap, bloodless conquest.

China's ambassador to Japan declared that "once the country of Japan is tied to the tanks plotting to split China, the Japanese people will be brought into the fire.”

US intelligence also believes that China is now working closely with the Russians on a Taiwan invasion scenario:

US intelligence officials assess that Russia and China are working more closely together on military issues, including a potential invasion of Taiwan, prompting new planning across the government to counter a potential scenario in which the countries fight in coordination.

In other words, if US intelligence is correct, an attack on Taiwan is likely to trigger a more general attack on democratic countries by the China-Russia axis.

Russia appears to be preparing for a more general confrontation with NATO in Europe. It recently removed the river buoys demarcating its border with Estonia. Estonia is the NATO country that's probably first in line to get invaded if Russia goes to war with NATO, given its small size and population, its exposed geographic position, and its large population of Russian speakers whose existence could provide Russia with an excuse for an攻击。

Meanwhile, Russia is stepping up what appears to be a sabotage campaign against Europe. Poland's prime minister has declared that Russia was likely behind the burning of a shopping mall in Warsaw, and many suspect that it was also behind a fire at Novo Nordisk's headquarters in Copenhagen. This is in addition to various other aggressive moves . It's not clear what all this is supposed to accomplish — scaring Europe into disunity and inaction, perhaps? — but it certainly seems to indicate an aggressive Russian posture toward NATO.

The reason Putin can be so confident in this slow-building aggression is that he knows his superpower ally has his back. Putin recently went to meet Xi in China , and the two promised to strengthen their “no limits partnership”. Xi even gave Putin a hug — a rare sign of personal affection from a Chinese leader.

And there's evidence that those words are being backed up with deeds. China is buying huge amounts of Russian oil, keeping the company's economy afloat. It's selling the Russians huge amounts of dual-use technology to keep its military machine humming despite Western sanctions. And the UK now believes that China is providing or preparing to provide Russia with lethal aid — actual weaponry — for the Ukraine war.

In other words, Zelikow appears to be absolutely right that the Xi-Putin partnership is a much more solid and active alliance than either the WW2 Axis or the Stalin-Mao cooperation in the early years of Cold War 1. Dreams of severing Russia from China by offering it Ukraine on a silver platter were always highly unrealistic, but now they're just utterly laughable. Nor will the threat of sanctions be sufficient to deter China from supporting its ally's war effort forever.

And Zelikow also appears to be absolutely right that this alliance has the strategic initiative — China and Russia are making all the moves, and the US and its allies are scrambling to respond. Yet respond we must.

What the US and its allies can do right now

Zelikow is not the first international relations scholar to identify the present moment as a crisis that will determine what type of conflict will unfold between the New Allies and the New Axis. In his book Danger Zone with Michael Beckley, my former colleague Hal Brands argues that cold wars are characterized by early pivot points or crises that can easily mushroom into all-out war. Only by shoring up deterrence and defining boundary lines can a cold war go truly cold — it's a sprint of a few years, followed by a marathon of a few decades.

Most of what I write about Cold War 2 is about what the US needs to do in order to prepare for the decades-long marathon. Reviving US manufacturing, restoring state capacity, strengthening old alliances and building new ones, maintaining America's technological edge, and so on — these are all efforts that would take many years to accomplish. Fortunately, I see a lot of other people coming to similar conclusions. For example, Matt Yglesias has an excellent post about how long-term national security requires us to embrace high-volume skilled immigration and expand trade with allies and potential allies:

But as crucial as these policies are, they will not get us through the “sprint” of the 2020s. The threat of world war is so imminent that even if we do all the long-term things right, we still have to figure out a way to deter China from attacking Taiwan in the short term.

One thing the US can do, as Elbridge Colby has argued, is to prioritize Asia over either Europe or the Middle East. This seems counterintuitive, since Asia is not currently at war, but Ukraine and Israel are. But the argument is based on capabilities rather than current events. China is the world's manufacturing powerhouse and could defeat all the other countries in Asia all on its own; Russia is a mid-sized power who couldn't hope to match the combined efforts of the European countries if they were to lend their full industrial strength to Ukraine. And the Middle East is simply strategically unimportant .

The US is more badly needed in Asia than anywhere else, and it's there we should concentrate our greatest attention and efforts. Europe simply has to step up and take the lead role in its own defense.

At the same time, the US should not abandon Ukraine aid. In my roundup this week , I cited a Brian Potter article about how the US was able to build up its defense industries before World War 2 broke out, so that it was prepared for the war when it came. One crucial factor, Potter writes, was demand for armaments from Britain and France:

The first push to grow the US aircraft industry came well before the US entered the war. Desperate for more planes to counter Hitler's territorial ambitions, both Britain and France placed large orders with US aircraft manufacturers in 1938 and 1939…This allowed US aircraft manufacturers to greatly expand their workforces, and industry employment tripled between 1938 and 1940. The orders also enabled manufacturers to build new, larger factories…

[I]n 1941 the US passed the Lend-Lease Act, which authorized $7 billion ($149 billion in 2024 dollars) to supply Allied nations with supplies and military equipment, including aircraft.

The Ukraine war is an important source of demand that will allow US defense producers to invest and ramp up production. Without it, the US' defense manufacturing weakness would never have been brought into the light; now, thanks to Ukraine, the US is increasing ammunition production . The ramp-up is still far too slow, but at least it's something. Remember that factories that are built to provide weapons to Ukraine can easily be repurposed to provide weapons to Taiwan in case war breaks out there.

But no matter what happens, the US is going to have to spend more on defense . This is going to be a difficult, bitter realization for many progressives who have spent their entire lives believing that America vastly outspends its rivals on defense, and that we should therefore cut defense spending in order to boost welfare spending. But a proper accounting shows that the US no longer outspends its rivals by a substantial amount. And defense has shriveled as a percent of US government spending, decade after decade. The progressive conventional wisdom of the 1990s no longer holds.

我原本不打算写一篇关于今天 Twitter 上的意外事件的文章……但是，一位朋友要求我这样做。我想这是了解美国精英社会和经济趋势的一个有趣的窗口。所以就这样吧。

今天的 Twitter 事件涉及耶鲁大学历史学博士后大卫·奥斯汀·沃尔什 (David Austin Walsh)。 （对于那些不知道的人来说，博士后职位是一种低薪炼狱，拥有博士学位的人在无法立即获得教授职位时被派去继续进行研究。）沃尔什是最近发布的一本书的作者书《夺回美国：保守派运动和极右翼》，但他最出名的身份是推特上直言不讳且固执己见的评论员。当我的播客联合主持人布拉德·德隆 (Brad DeLong)在 2019 年宣布，像他这样的新自由主义者是时候将接力棒“传递给更左翼的同事”时，他引用了沃尔什的一条推文。近年来，沃尔什花了很多时间从左翼角度攻击乔·拜登。自加沙战争开始以来，这些袭击变得更加猛烈。

但这并不是让 Twitter（或者现在正式称为 X）今天感到兴奋的原因。相反，沃尔什宣称，他未能获得终身教职的学术工作至少部分是由于他是白人这一事实：

当一位（非白人、女性）历史教授对这一说法提出异议时，他指责她从她的权力地位上“压制”他。

这激怒了推特上的所有人，从谴责沃尔什只是一个更平庸的白人、认为自己比女性和有色人种更有资格的进步派，到嘲笑沃尔什是因为支持不公平的崛起而自找麻烦的保守派。 DEI 政权。各方唯一一致的一点是，他们都鄙视沃尔什。接下来是一场为期一天的大逃杀。沃尔什发表了结结巴巴的道歉，但很明显，他实际上相信自己比获得他所申请工作的人更有资格：

我确实认为学术招聘中的歧视问题有点有趣，我稍后会谈到这个问题。但沃尔什事件更让我感兴趣的是，它似乎提供了精英生产过剩的一个例子。

大约一年半前，我写了一篇文章，提出了一个假设，解释为什么过去十年美国知识精英中有如此多的不满：

基本观点1是，受过教育的精英的许多职业——人文和社会科学学术界、法律、新闻界等——几乎在同一时间开始变得越来越稀缺。这不可避免地导致了一群抱有很大期望但却无法实现的沮丧的奋斗者。我推测，期望与机会之间的不匹配加剧了 2010 年代的一些动荡。

大卫·奥斯汀·沃尔什似乎是我所描述的社会过程的完美例子。他接受过极其精英的教育——他就读于明尼苏达大学，并在普林斯顿大学获得博士学位。他显然对自己的能力评价很高，从他计划写一篇文章来解释为什么他比所有最终被录用的人更有资格来看。有一次，当他参加 LSAT 练习时，成绩不佳，他将自己的表现归咎于试题“右翼”。

这种崇高的自尊很容易导致对职业成就的高期望。很明显，沃尔什不仅希望获得一份终身教职的学术工作，还希望在他的特定研究领域——20 世纪美国历史——中找到一份工作。虽然这样的工作并不多，但这正是沃尔什的目标。正是他未能在那个特定领域找到特定的工作，这让他感到沮丧，并在帖子中猛烈抨击，这让每个人都感到愤怒。

总是很可能有人会因为这个原因而感到沮丧。如今，历史学教授职位是极其稀缺的商品。很多人仍在攻读历史学博士学位，但历史学教授职位的广告在大衰退中崩溃了，并且再也没有恢复过来：

大部分倒闭都集中在助理教授的职位上——沃尔什试图获得的入门级教授职位。

为什么没有人聘请历史学家？有四个基本原因。第一个也是最重要的——几乎没有人谈论过，因为它应该是显而易见的——是美国大学系统基本上已经完成了扩张。 20 世纪出现了大规模的大学建设，这需要雇用大量的终身教授。然后它停止了。由于终身教职是终身制，现有大学的院系里挤满了大批老教授，他们直到年老才离开。因此，新员工的招聘速度必须缓慢，因为只要教授的数量大致恒定，他们就只能被雇佣来替代退休或去世的人。

第二个原因是 2008 年 9 月经济大衰退期间对大学造成的资金紧缩。这次经济衰退给国家预算带来了很大压力，而州立大学的支出是他们可以削减的一件事。 他们就这么做了。当经济复苏时，一些州并没有恢复经济衰退前的融资水平。大学通过提高学费来弥补收入损失，这让所有人都抓狂了。

这些学费上涨的时机并不合适，因为现在没有人雇用历史学家的第三个原因是： 大学入学率本身正在下降。部分原因是美国年轻人的数量大部分已经停止增长。部分原因是自世纪之交以来，高等教育的经济收益——大学工资溢价—— 一直在缓慢萎缩。

保费下降对国家来说可能是一件好事——最可能的原因是我们送了太多美国人上大学，导致受过教育的工人过剩。但是，当一个国家的孩子越来越少，而他们面临着更高的价格而接受的教育价值较低时，你可能会看到更少的人上大学。这意味着总体上对教授的需求减少。

但对历史学家的需求下降还有第四个原因：大学生越来越回避历史专业。就在大衰退之前，历史学学位在文学学士学位中所占的比例达到了顶峰，从那时起，他们的比例就彻底崩溃了：

总的来说，学生们纷纷从人文学科和非经济社会科学领域涌入，涌入他们认为能为自己提供更好就业前景的计算机科学等领域。历史是受打击最严重的时期之一。

历史学家可能将研究视为他们的主要工作，但大学对历史教授的需求很大程度上取决于历史专业本科生的数量。如果这个数字急剧下降，你就不会看到历史学家有多少终身职位。与此同时，国家预算的削减和学费的下降正在促进兼职教师和讲师的崛起，而不是终身教职人员的崛起。

因此，虽然半个世纪前，终身教授的历史职位相对充足，但如今却极其稀缺——试图成为一名终身历史教授并不完全像试图成为电影明星或毒枭，但它确实已经发生了变化。朝那个方向。

当某个领域的工作机会稀缺时，基于身份和代表性的斗争就会加剧。当大量申请者都在争夺一份工作时，胜负之间的差距往往非常狭窄。这自然会让人担心被选中的人有一些不公平的优势。如果白人被选中，非白人可能会怀疑种族歧视；如果选择了有色人种，白人可能会怀疑 DEI 的影响。职位的竞争越激烈，即使是很小的不公平优势也会打破平衡的可能性就越大。

这符合我关于美国人如何看待种族和性别歧视的一般理论。在有关大学招生的民意调查中，美国人强烈支持“平权行动” ，并强烈反对在招生中考虑种族因素。但这些都是同一个东西！美国民意调查的受访者可能只是不明白他们所回答的问题。但我怀疑是别的东西。我认为美国人喜欢有利于代表性不足的群体的非官方的、默认的歧视，但也非常重视个人公平的想法，因此不喜欢官方的、基于规则的歧视。

这两个目标之间存在天然的张力。当形势好的时候——当对代表性不足的群体的优惠推动仍然会让代表性过高的群体表现良好时——有可能甚至很容易忽视这种紧张关系。你可以告诉自己，即使平权行动对招生或招聘等产生偏见，总蛋糕也在不断变大，因此总体上没有任何群体实际上受到伤害。增长压倒了对分配的担忧。但当形势不好时，游戏变成零和甚至负和，就不可能维持这种快乐的心理二元性。因此，关于种族和性别偏好的争论再次爆发。

因此，在历史领域看到种族和性别之争对我来说完全不足为奇。与许多人文学科和非经济社会科学领域一样，学术史正在萎缩，这几乎完全是由似乎不太可能很快改变的结构性因素驱动的。争夺剩余资源的斗争将不可避免地变得激烈。

在我看来，更大的问题是这对我们更广泛的社会产生什么影响。精英生产过剩理论基本上认为，职业期望无法得到满足的受过教育的精英将通过对更广泛的社会感到愤怒并煽动骚乱来做出反应。当然，大卫·奥斯汀·沃尔什（David Austin Walsh）作为一名尖锐的社交媒体呼喊者的充满争议的职业生涯符合这一预测。我们刚刚度过了一个十年，在这个十年中，尖锐的社交媒体呼喊者对我们的国家话语和社会政治文化拥有不成比例的权力。坦率地说，这对美国来说并不好。

那么我们如何对抗精英生产过剩呢？显而易见的方法是为受过教育的精英提供更多的职业机会，但这可能会给整个社会带来极高的成本。像沃尔什这样的人对自己的职业抱有非常狭隘、具体的期望，要满足所有这些期望，就需要将大量最有才华的人分流到本质上是赚钱的工作中。我们无法支付每个人成为他们选择的人文或社会科学领域的终身教授的费用。

相反，我认为这个问题需要改变期望。我认为大衰退和新冠疫情确实在这方面有所帮助，让很多人不再相信他们的生活将是通往繁荣、名誉和尊重的滑行之路。所以那里有一些重置。最重要的是，我们可能应该在历史等领域减少博士生的数量，因为这些领域的学术工作稀缺，私营部门的职业前景也并不明显。

（当然，美国父母可能应该停止告诉他们的孩子，他们是世界上最聪明的孩子，他们注定会变得伟大，等等。但我非常怀疑美国父母是否会停止告诉他们的孩子这一点.)

但除此之外，我认为学术顾问和其他有影响力的人物应该努力让受过教育的人们的期望更加模糊。 “我将成为一所优秀大学的 20 世纪美国历史领域的终身教授”是一个非常具体的期望，但很难实现。 “我将找到一份报酬不错的工作，做一些智力上有趣的事情，同时也许还可以写一本书”是一个非常模糊的期望，几乎所有美国博士学位持有者都可以实现。美国奋斗者需要学会顺着生活的风向前进。听我的——这样更有趣。
